a.g: Woe to those who give less [than due],
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Indeed, one must measure as he would be measured. Allah the Exalted has said: **"Woe to the defrauders [al-mutaffifin]â€”those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full, but when they measure or weigh for them, they give less."** (83:1-3). And one is not saved from this except by giving more when he gives and taking less when he takes, for true justice [al-'adl al-haqiqi] is scarcely conceivable. So let him seek the clear evidence of increase and decrease. For whoever exacts his right in its entirety is on the verge of transgressing it. And some of them would say: "I will not purchase Woe from Allah for a single grain." So when he would take, he would decrease by half a grain, and when he would give, he would increase by a grain. And he would say: "Woe to him who sells for a single grain a Paradise whose width is the heavens and the earth. And how great is the loss of him who sells bliss [tuba] for woe [wil]!" And they were excessive in guarding against this and its like because they are injustices [mazalim] from which repentance is not possible, for the owners of the grains are not known so that one could gather them and fulfill their rights. And for that reason, when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, purchased something, he said to the weigher as he was weighing its price: "Weigh, and give more." A hadith states: He said to the weigher, "Weigh, and give more." Narrated by the compilers of the Sunan and al-Hakim from the hadith of Suwayd ibn Qays. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih." And al-Hakim said: "Sahih according to the conditions of Muslim." And Fudayl looked at his son as he was washing a dinar, intending to exchange it and remove its blackening and purify it so that its weight would not increase because of that, and he said: "O my son, your doing this is better than two Hajj pilgrimages and twenty 'Umrahs." And some of the predecessors said: "I am amazed at the merchant and the sellerâ€”how can he be saved? He weighs and swears by day, and sleeps by night." And Sulayman, peace be upon him, said to his son: "O my son, just as a grain enters between two stones, so does a sin enter between the two parties in a transaction." And one of the righteous prayed over an effeminate man, and it was said to him: "He was a sinner [fasiq]." So he remained silent. It was repeated to him, and he said: "It is as if you are telling me he was the owner of two scales: he would give with one and take with the other." He indicated by this that his sin was an injustice between him and Allah the Exalted. And this is from the injustices against servants [mazalim al-'ibad], and being lax and forgiving in it is more remote. And the severity in the matter of the scale is great, and salvation from it is achieved by a grain and half a grain. And in the recitation of 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: **"Do not transgress in the measure, and establish the weight with fairness, and do not diminish the measure"**â€”meaning the tongue of the scale, for decrease and increase appear by its inclination. And in summary, everyone who demands full justice for himself from others, even in a word, but does not give justice in like manner, he falls under the saying of Allah the Exalted: **"Woe to the defraudersâ€”those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full..."** (83:1-3). For the prohibition of that in what is measured is not because it is something measured, but because it is a quantified matter in which justice and fairness have been abandoned. Thus, it applies to all actions. So the owner of the scale is in danger of the Woe, and every legally responsible person is an owner of scales in his actions, his words, and his thoughts. So the Woe is for him if he deviates from justice [al-'adl] and inclines away from uprightness [al-istiqamah]. And were it not for the difficulty and near-impossibility of this, His saying, the Exalted, would not have come: **"And there is none of you but will come to it. This is upon your Lord an inevitability decreed."** (19:71). So no servant is freeâ€”who is not protected from sinâ€”from inclining away from uprightness, except that the degrees of inclination vary with a great variation. Therefore, the duration of their stay in the Fire varies until the time of deliverance, so that some remain only for the duration of fulfilling an oath, and some remain for a thousand and thousands of years. So we ask Allah the Exalted to bring us close to uprightness and justice, for adhering firmly to the straight path [al-sirat al-mustaqim] without any deviation from it is not something to be hoped for, for it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword. And were it not for that, the one upright upon it would not be able to cross the Sirat stretched over the midst of the Fire, whose description is that it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword. And according to one's uprightness on this straight path, the servant is lightened on the Day of Resurrection upon the Sirat. And everyone who mixes food with dirt or other, then measures it, he is from the defrauders in measuring. And every butcher who weighs bone with meat in a manner not customary, he is from the defrauders in weighing. And judge by this all other estimations, even in the cubit measurement undertaken by the cloth merchant. For when he buys, he releases the cloth at the time of measuring and does not stretch it fully, and when he sells it, he stretches it in the measurement to make it appear more.

Indeed, and woe [wa-wail] for him in the explicit text of the Book of Allah, the Exalted, where He said: "Woe to the defrauders [al-mutaffifin]â€”those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full, but when they measure or weigh for them, they give less." And everyone who seeks from fairness [al-insaf] more than what his own soul [nafs] permits, he falls under the implication of this verse. And the origin of the shortcoming in covering the private parts [satr al-'awrah] or striving to expose them is the hidden disease [al-da' al-dafin] within the inner self [al-batin], which is rancor [al-hiqd] and envy [al-hasad]. For the rancorous, envious one fills his inner self [batin] with malice [al-khabath], but he restrains it within his inner self and conceals it, and does not reveal it as long as he does not find an opportunity for it. And when he finds an opening, the bond is loosened and modesty [al-haya'] is lifted, and the inner self seeps with its hidden malice. And whenever the inner self harbors rancor and envy, then disengagement [al-inqita'] is more fitting.

a.g: Who, when they take a measure from people, take in full.
But if they give by measure or by weight to them, they cause loss.
Do they not think that they will be resurrected
For a tremendous Day -
The Day when mankind will stand before the Lord of the worlds?

Indeed, then contemplate the crowding of creation [al-khalq] and their gathering, until the inhabitants of the seven heavens and the seven earthsâ€”from angel, jinn, human, devil, beast, predator, and birdâ€”are crowded upon the Standing Place [al-Mawqif]. Then it is brought near to the heads of the worlds [al-'alamin] like the distance of two bow-lengths. There remains on the earth no shade except the shade of the Lord of the worlds [Rabb al-'alamin], and none can take shelter in it except those brought near [al-Muqarrabun]. So between one taking shelter beneath the Throne [al-'Arsh] and one exposed to the sun's heat, which melts him with its heat, his distress and anguish intensify from its blaze. So the blaze of the sun, the heat of breaths, and the burning of hearts [qulub] with the fire of modesty [al-haya'] and fear [al-khawf] combine. Then sweat flows from the root of every hair until it streams upon the plain of the Resurrection [al-Qiyamah]. Then it rises upon their bodies according to the measure of their stations [manazil] with Allah. For some, the sweat reaches his knees; for some, his waist; for some, to his earlobes; and for some, he is nearly submerged in it. Among them is one who calls out, saying: "My Lord, relieve me from this distress and waiting, even if to the Fire." And all of that, and they have not yet faced the Reckoning [al-hisab] or the punishment [al-'iqab]. For you are one of them, and you do not know to where the sweat will reach you.

Indeed, the drink [sharab] is an expression for the totality of the bliss of Paradise [jinan], just as the book [kitab] was used as an expression for all deeds, as He said: "Indeed, the record of the righteous [al-abrar] is in 'Illiyyun." Then He said: "Witnessed by those brought near [al-muqarrabun]." Thus, it was a sign that the cause of their record was its elevation to where it is witnessed by those brought near. And just as the righteous find increase in their state and their knowledge [ma'rifa] through their proximity to those brought near and their witnessing of them, so too will be their state in the Hereafter: "He did not create you nor resurrect you except as a single soul. As We began the first creation, We will repeat it." And as the Almighty said: "A reward in accordance [jaza'an wifaqan]" â€” meaning the reward corresponded to their deeds. So the pure was met with the pure from the drink, and the mixed was met with the mixed. And the mixture [shawb] of every drink is according to the measure of what preceded of mixture in his love [hubb] and his deeds. "So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." â€” "And indeed, Allah does not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves." â€” "Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight. And if there is a good deed, He multiplies it." â€” "And if it is the weight of a mustard seed, We will bring it forth. And sufficient are We as accountants." So whoever, in this world [dunya], his love was his hope for the bliss of Paradise, the maidens with large, [beautiful] eyes, and the palaces, he is granted power in Paradise to settle wherever he wishes, to play with the eternal youths and enjoy the women. There, in the Hereafter, his pleasure ends, for indeed, every person is given in love what his soul [nafs] desires and his eye delights in. But whoever his aim was the Lord of the Abode and the Owner of Sovereignty, and nothing dominated him except his love with sincerity [ikhlas] and truthfulness [sidq], he is settled "in a seat of honor near a Sovereign, Perfect in Ability." Thus, the righteous graze in the gardens and delight in the Paradises with the maidens and the eternal youths, while those brought near are constant in the Presence [al-hadra], devoted, their gaze fixed upon It. They consider the bliss of Paradise insignificant compared to an atom of It. For some people are preoccupied with satisfying the appetite of the belly and the private parts, and for companionship there are other people. And for this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The majority of the inhabitants of Paradise are the simple-minded, and 'Illiyyun is for the people of understanding." And when understandings fell short of grasping the meaning of 'Illiyyun, He magnified its matter, saying: "And what can make you know what is 'Illiyyun?" just as the Almighty said: "The Striking Calamity - what is the Striking Calamity? And what can make you know what is the Striking Calamity?"
